/coingossip.content: Simplifying the tracking of news articles and social media discussions about cryptocurrencies.

content: To try out CoinGossip,
ðŸ‘ˆ

During the cryptocurrency hype in 2018, there was a high volume of online discussions and speculations about cryptocurrencies across multiple social media platforms. However, as these discussions were extremely disorganised, many users (especially investors and market speculators) found it difficult to obtain insightful information regarding any specific cryptocurrency.
To tackle this issue, I set out to solve the following pain points:
Know what cyptocurrencies are currently trending in real-time
Have a list of news articles or disucsssion threads to provide context of trending cryptocurrencies
Determine the overall sentiment of the trending cryptocurrency, without having to read through the news or discussions manually
See the price actions in context of the trends and sentiment

Cryptocurrencies are listed in terms of their popularity on the internet ("Gossip"). For example, when evaluating a single Reddit post that is related to a cryptocurrency, CoinGossip will also include its title, its upvotes and its comments into consideration.
Data visualisation aids are used as well, including a pie chart and a scoreboard.

Users can quickly view all related headlines or discussions for any cryptocurrency. To reduce the need for manually reading every news item, a machine learning algorithm is applied to deduce the overall Sentiment of each news item. The sentiment can be seen from thumbs up (positive) and thumbs down (negative) icon.

As CoinGossip gained popularity, many users began submitting their feature suggestions. This led to the development of many user-requested features, with the most requested one being a historical trend analysis for custom cryptocurrencies.

/smartmirror.content: An easily deployable front-end dashboard that is compatible with most Smart Mirror installations.

content: In 2017, the popularity of the Raspberry Pi and IOT devices has led to an
A smart mirror is a two-way mirror with an electronic display behind the glass, which can show the viewer different kinds of information in the form of widgets.
My goal was to build a web based front end interface that can be easily used for smart mirror installations, and even standalone kiosk devices. Specifically, I wanted the UI to achieve the following:
View date and time information
Animated visuals of the current temperature and weather
News ticker that provides the latest headlines
See the price actions of stocks and cryptocurrencies
This Smart Mirror UI is written completely using web technologies (HTML, Javascript) as a Single-Page-Application (SPA). It relies on other JSON APIs for its upstream information, such as:
Data.gov.sg for weather information
rss2json for news headlines
Yahoo Finance for stock prices
CoinMarketCap for cryptocurrency prices
As an SPA, it is easy to deploy to any lightweight IOT devices across many CPU architectures (arm, x86) and operating systems (Android, Linux distros, Windows IoT).
This project was completed in December 2017.

/alastair.content: A private cloud-less home automation platform that serves an ecosystem of IOT smart devices and sensors.

content: As IOT devices and sensors become increasingly cheaper and more sophiscated, the prospect of an connected smart home is now an inevitability. However, almost all implementaions of smart home devices requires a third party service provider (Amazon Alexa, Xiaomi Mi Home, Nest, Samsung Smart Things), which raises potential security concerns.
Back in 2016, I was very interested in building my own smart home using IOT boards and sensors. I set out to achieve the following:
A smart home implementation without any reliance on third party (cloud) services
Wifi enabled eletrical outlets, lights and cooling (fan and air conditioners)
Automatic regulation of lighting and cooling devices based on room temperature and ambient light
User presence detection, so as to turn off devices when user is off premise
Occupancy detection, so as to know number of users that are currently in the house
Security camera, with footage that can be streamed over the internet
As a full stack solution, the Alastair project consists of many hardware and software components.
On the hardware side, it involved the following:
Raspberry Pi 1 Model B+ (the main server)
Wifi and Bluetooth USB dongles (for Raspberry Pi)
Kankun ESP8266 Wifi Plug (with OpenWRT)
Yeelight Light Bulbs (with Developer Mode turned on)
Keyes TSOP1838 IR Receiver
IR LED
DS18B20 Temperature Sensor
LM393 Light Sensor
PIR Motion Sensor
Alcatel One Touch Pixi 3 (repurposed as security camera)
On the software side, it involved the following:
Python watchdog scripts, which performs automated control over devices based on real-time sensors and device information
Custom OpenWRT scripts for Kankun ESP8266
LIRC, for infared interfacing with air conditioners
EventGhost, an automation tool for Windows devices
Python communication scripts, for interfacing with devices over Wifi
Python sensor scripts, to convert analog sensor informaton into digital data
Bash scripts, for performing Wifi ARP scans and Bluetooth beacon detection
Web server, to provide the front-end hybrid application for desktop and mobile use
